I keep saying the opposite of democracy is apathy. We are not helpless. As I look at this positive test, I am not scared or feel helpless because a lot of Americans stared down this pandemic over last 2yrs and worked hard together to solve problems and get tools/treatments.9/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FN5VNjqWYAYJ95f.jpg

In my congressional district, it‚Äôs worse. 1 in about 200 of my neighbors and constituents died of COVID. I‚Äôll never be able to fully grapple with that staggering scale of loss. Let us not be numb to the loss. We can move forward while still honoring those we lost. 8/10

But it also came at great cost. Some time in the next few weeks we will hit 1 million killed in our country. 1 in 330 Americans have died of COVID. That ratio holds true in Congress. Of 435 members and 100 senators, two have died. 1 in 267 in Congress have died of COVID. 7/10

I think it‚Äôs important to keep some reflection on the last two yrs. We‚Äôve been through a lot. We have a lot of resilience. None of us had ever been through anything like this before. We had to be more adaptive than probably any other time in our lives. 6/10

I was also fearful that the economy was about to bottom out. Stock market dropping 1000s a day. People were talking about not just recession but possible depression. Felt like the world was falling apart around us. 5/10

It was near impossible to get a test. I still remember discomfort of the first nasal swab. It took over 6 days for results. Vaccines were just a hopeful dream. I was terrified because I was with elderly family and little kids and couldn‚Äôt bear if they got sick, esp from me. 4/10

I‚Äôm not scared now but I was 2 yrs ago. This time 2020, a colleague who I had just spent time with tested positive. He is a healthy man in his 40s who still had to go on ventilator in a hospital. Because of my exposure, I quarantined in March 2020 as panic gripped our nation.3/10

The JCPOA didn't cover every instance of Iran's rogue behavior ‚Äì but it was better than no deal at all, and we should explore every possible opportunity alongside our allies and partners to return to it.

We have to give diplomacy a chance, especially on subjects this important.

The JCPOA included monitoring and verification measures for the global community to closely track Iran's nuclear program, and it imposed limits on Iran's ability to acquire a nuclear weapon.

Withdrawing from the deal cleared these crucial roadblocks from Iran's nuclear path.

Trump's withdrawal from the JCPOA and his administration‚Äôs strategy of ‚Äúmaximum pressure‚Äù failed.

With the United States out of the JCPOA, Iran reduced its breakout time for getting a nuclear weapon and doubled down on its malign activities throughout the region.

When the last administration withdrew from the JCPOA, I warned that withdrawal would not address Iran's malign actions in the Middle East or prevent Tehran from getting a nuclear weapon.

Continued efforts to restore the deal are challenging, but crucial. https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-wont-negotiate-ukraine-related-sanctions-with-russia-to-save-iran-nuclear-deal-11647167692
